section.title: Graph
section.para: A graph is an ordered pair G = (V, E).

listitem.para: V is an ordered set of vertices V = (v_1, v_2, ...).
E is an ordered set of edges E = (e_1, e_2, ...).
An edge e ∈ E is an unordered pair of vertices: e = {v_i, v_j}, i≠j, v ∈ V.

section.para: This design differs from the general definition of a graph in the following ways:

listitem.para: In the general definition, V is an unordered set: V = {v_1, v_2, ...}.
We use an ordered set, because this allows to get the same results with different runs of a program that processes the same graph (reproducability).
In the general definition, E is an unordered set: E = {e_1, e_2, ...}.
We again use 'ordered' instead of 'unordered' to achieve reproducability.
